content:
Potential energy of the configuration arises due to the potential energy of one dipole (say,  $\mathbf{Q}$ ) in the magnetic field due to other (P). Use the result that the field due to  $\mathbf{P}$  is given by the expression [Eqs. (5.4) and (5.5)]:

$$
\mathbf {B} _ {\mathrm {P}} = - \frac {\mu_ {0}}{4 \pi} \frac {\mathbf {m} _ {\mathrm {P}}}{r ^ {3}} \quad (\text {o n t h e n o r m a l b i s e c t o r})
$$

$$
\mathbf {B} _ {\mathrm {P}} = \frac {\mu_ {0} 2}{4 \pi} \frac {\mathbf {m} _ {\mathrm {P}}}{r ^ {3}} \quad (\text {o n t h e a x i s})
$$
summary: The text discusses the potential energy of a configuration composed of two dipoles and the expression of the field due to one (say, $\mathbf{P}$) in the magnetic field due to the other ($\mathbf{Q}$)
hypothetical_questions: What is the field due to one dipole in the magnetic field of the other?
How is the potential energy of the configuration arising?
What is the potential energy of one dipole in the magnetic field due to another?
What are the two equations that provide the expression for the field due to $\mathbf{P}$?
